title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: many reels were danced ; Campbell of Monzie is an exceedingly good dancer.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: The Belhavens, Seftons, Cravens, Campbell of Monzie, and various others composed the party.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We got out there a moment to look at the very fine house he is building, then drove home by Monzie (Campbell of Monzie's), and Sir W. Murray's, and had a very good view of the Highland hills — a very fine day.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Campbell of Monzie (pronounced "Monie"), a young gentleman who has a place near here, went with him and Avas, Albert said, extremely active.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: After dinnermore people came^several in kilts; and manyreels were danced : Campbell of Monzie is an exceedingly good dancer.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Monzie, a parish of Scotland, in Perthshire, 12 miles long, and 7 broad.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: Lord Lovat, who, on account of his numerous law-pleas, was a great intimate of Lord Alva's, frequently visited him here ; and Mrs Campbell of Monzie, Lord Alva's daughter, used to tell, that when she

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: " We passed three days and three nights with liim, one at Ochtertyre  and another at Monzie, and fain would I have gone down the country, as I had never been farther up before than at Lord Kinnoul's.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: He left no son but Lieutenant-General Alexander Campbell of Monzie, the heir of his father's sagacity and talents, with more experience in war.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: Quitting the town by the new road to Perth, thehouse of Ferntower, (Sir David Baird,) appeared onour left, under the well- wooded Knock of Crieff ; andshortly beyond, a road led to Monzie, the beautifulseat of General Campbell, while that which we pursued ran along the mid-side of a hiU, cultivated to itshighest ridge, and commanding a fine and extensiveview of the valley of the Earn, which now expandedinto a wide and fertile strath, bounded towards thesouth by the Ochil hills, which rose in sunny love-
